raw_response: {"answer_index": 0, "answer_text": "Ventricular shunting", "confidence": 10, "reasoning": "This patient presents with the classic triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH): gait disturbance (broad-based, slow, short steps), urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment (inattention, impaired recall, disorientation). NPH is treated with ventricular shunting, which can improve symptoms. The other options do not address the underlying pathophysiology of NPH.", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
